problems.title: Lesson 0.1 Using CLUE and Dataflow Programming

text: Welcome to CLUE
On the right is your workspace. To edit your workspace, you must first add a tile. You get a tile in your workspace by either

• Dragging a tile from the content (left side) in CLUE into your workspace
  • Dragging a new tile from the menu on the left of your workspace
  • Click a button on the menu to add a new tile to the bottom of your workspace

All tiles have a waffle (gray box with six dots) in the upper right corner if you hover over it. To drag the tile, click the waffle and hold it down as you drag it to your workspace. As you drag the tile into the workspace, a blue line shows where the tile will go when you let go.
OK, get ready... Here we go!
Introduction to tool types
Try to make a text tile in your Workspace on the right (press the menu button with the letter A on it). Write down some things you hope to learn in this Neural Engineering class.
Now insert an image into your workspace. You can upload using the button or you can drag images from your desktop. Describe in your workspace how you might use images to document your work.
Finally, try to make a table. Fill the table in with some data, and change the column header names to something you might use for engineering design. Describe the meaning of your data in text.

Because these lessons are about engineering and robotics, you will also need a programming tool that can read sensor data and control outputs. In this course, the programming tool is called Dataflow, and it can be launched from the button with two connected boxes. Programs can be simple, adding or comparing two numbers, or sophisticated, with many nodes that control outputs based on inputs.
Below is a sample program. Try to make one of your own that adds two numbers. What are the different ways that you see the result of the program?
Group work - discussion

CLUE is designed to facilitate sharing of ideas, both in small lab groups and with the whole class. When you are ready to work in a group, you can split your workspace into 4 panes. The top right pane is yours, and your partners are in the others. You can borrow and update content from your partners' workspaces just as you can from any content you bring up from tabs on the left hand Resources.
Try Group Sharing
First, check that all the members of your group have the same group number at the top right of your screen.
Talk about robots and bionic limbs with your group. What do you know about bionics?
Take some notes on your discussion in your Workspace.
Take notes and make a list of what your group knows. Insert some images in your workspace relating to motion and robotics.
When ready, share with the group

Use the group controls in the upper right of your workspace so that you can see and share each others' notes. See the image below for how to do that. Take a look at the list of terms in your groupmates' windows. You can drag tiles from their windows into yours, or just get ideas from what they have done.
Making new workspaces

At the top of the Workspace window you will see a File menu. Using this menu you can make copies of your existing workspace to try different things, or you can start a whole new one. This is very useful if you are trying different versions of a program to solve a problem.
Discuss the research questions
Work with the members of your group to explore each other's questions and ideas.
Publish your work to the class

You can choose one member of your group to publish a summary of the group's work, or you may each publish. When you publish, your workspace will appear under the pink "Extensions" tab above. Student work will go under the Class Models and Data tab. Teacher work will go under the Custom Lessons tab.
Teacher Features

If you are looking at this Lesson as a teacher, you are seeing this green box with a 'solution' in it. You can choose to switch the solutions on and off so you can see Lessons as students do. You will also see additional tabs in your Resources - one for Teacher Guide and one for Student Worksheets.

The Teacher Guide will have a variety of resources in it - materials sheets, instructions for running class activities, links to outside web sites, videos, etc. As with all other content in the Resources tabs, you can drag tiles into your Workspace so they can be modified or published to distribute to the class. This is particularly handy if you want to add an additional lesson or page of solutions or instructions to any of the existing Lessons. You can use the same publishing tool available to your students. Teacher published work will appear in the Custom Lessons tab under 'Extensions'.

problems.title: Lesson 1.1 - What is a bionic arm?

text: Objective:
During this lesson, we will explore emerging robotics technology that helps people with neurological conditions or missing limbs.
Let's Explore Energy Sticks!
Please watch the video to explore what energy sticks are: Energy Stick Video

Try creating some tiles in your workspace and write down some thoughts about what Energy sticks are and how they work. You can make text tiles (letter A), drawings (pencil), Tables and graphs, including pictures or photos, and even make programs, which we will work with in future lessons.
In their CLUE Workspace, students should reflect critically about their readings and any questions they have brainstormed. Have students try out some of the tools to document what they learned.
Experiment with Energy Sticks
Please pair up with the friend and play with the energy stick provided. While playing with it, you can try any of these activities:

• compare each partner holding one end of the energy stick with one hand and keeping your other hand at your sides with holding one end of the energy stick while simultaneously holding hands with your partner.
  • compare holding one end of the energy stick while simultaneously holding one end of a piece of wood (e.g., wooden spoon) with holding one end of the energy stick while simultaneously holding one end of a piece of metal (e.g., metal spoon).
Document the results of each experiment. Then try making up a few experiments of your own. What does each trial prove?
Programs to Express Closing a Circuit
We can use a program to turn lights on and off in the same way you just did with the Energy Sticks.

Here is a very simple program. Recreate this program with the Dataflow program tool in your workspace. Start by pressing the tile button with two blocks and a connector line. Then try adding some logic to make the lightbulb only turn on when the signal amplitude is over 0.5.
Programs are one way to express models of actual circuits.
DISCUSS
Let's Discuss your shared experience of playing with the energy sticks and what you have observed! Some questions you could think about are:

• What makes our classroom light glow? (Flick light switch off) Why does flicking the switch stop the light from glowing?
  • What conditions appear to be necessary to make the light stick glow? What conditions appear to be necessary to make the light stick not glow? How can this be explained?
How do Bionic Arms Work?
Please watch one of the following videos to learn about the bionic arms:
Tilly’s Bionic Arms
Beyond Robotics
Working in Groups

Please practice working in groups using the group sharing tools in CLUE. Switch to the Group View and share your documents. Swap ideas about what you saw in the Bionic Arm videos, and how you think they relate to the energy stick.
Drag the table below into your learning log, and fill it in for this experiment.
KWL JOURNAL

You will keep a journal of what you have learned throughout these lessons. Begin or Open a KWL Journal either from the File menu or from the My Work tab. Record today's date. Then drag the table below into your journal and fill it out.

content.name: After each activity, please record what you know, wonder, and learn about the topic.

text: Objective
During this lesson, we will measure their own reaction times, construct a model to communicate their current understanding, and investigate how neurological conditions could impact limb movement.
Let's measure our reaction times!
DISCUSS
Let's discuss how fast human limbs can react in day-to-day life (e.g., the time it takes to start crossing the street once the light changes to green). Some questions you could think about are:

• What affects limb reaction time (RT)?
  • Why is time to react important?
Document your thoughts in your workspace
WATCH
Please watch this video to explore what reaction time is all about.
Document in your worksheet what you learned in the video.
TRY
Please pair up with a friend and measure your reaction times using your dominant and non-dominant hands.
Please follow the instructions video here.
You can drag the data tables into your workspace to record your scores (You can also print out the form).
Use the lookup table to convert drop distance (in cm) to time (in thousands of a second).
Results Table
Drag these tables into your Workspace and fill them in to record and calculate your results
* indicates final results
If your teacher has provided a Google sheet, please enter your data there to compute the class average.
You may wish to create a Google sheet for your class to calculate the average scores for all students. Create a text region in a CLUE worksheet and put a link to the sheet.
TRY (Optional)
Please take a video of yourself catching an object and play it in slow motion. Please watch the example video.
On iPhone: Go into the camera and click “Slo-mo” to take slow motion video
On Android: Go into the camera, click “video” and then select “slow motion” option.
Document the links to your videos in your workspace and share them with your class.
DISCUSS

Once one member from each group shares their model, please compare and contrast the models to identify what is similar and different and document these in your worksheet. You can use text, drawings, or any other representation that helps you talk about your model.
Similarities
Differences

After the Investigating how injury to different parts of the nervous system might impact limb movement group work (I am not sure how to structure these because the lesson will be jumping from group work to class work and class work to group work):
SHARE

Each group will share their findings for the question of how injury to different parts of the nervous system might impact limb movement. For this section, you can share your screen in group view (rectangle icon in the upper right of the screen). Or you can publish to Class Work (rectangle with up arrow in the upper left of the screen) and ask others to look at your model on their computers while one member of the group shares the group's results.
KWL JOURNAL

You will keep a journal of what you have learned throughout these lessons. Begin or Open a KWL Journal either from the File menu or from the My Work tab. Record today's date. Then drag the table below into your journal and fill it out.

content.name: After each activity, please record what you know, wonder, and learn about the topic.

text: Marking the Components of the Nervous System
Please review this digital resource on the nervous system, and mark the components of the nervous system (brain, spinal cord, and peripheral nerves) on your model from the previous lesson.
Please list all body systems that affect our reaction time. Then, co-construct an illustrated and annotated model of the sequence of events associated with the reaction time activity.
List the body systems in a text tile in your workspace. Draw your model on the drawing tile.

What are other ways you could model the nervous system. Can you make a program that simulates what happens when your brain tells your arm to move? Can you make a plot of moments in time that signals move in the body? Can you make a physical model and take a picture of it?
DISCUSS
Select a member as a spokesperson to share your model with the class.
Investigating how injury to different parts of the nervous system might impact limb movement

Please select one of the following injuries to explore more, and then mark the location of the injury/disorder on your model and add text that communicates some ways you predict limb movement would be affected. (Here again, the students need to be able to mark on their model. So, a larger section for their model might be better.)
Brain Injury reference document
Spinal Cord Injury reference document
Peripheral Nerve Injury reference document
KWL JOURNAL

You will keep a journal of what you have learned throughout these lessons. Begin or Open a KWL Journal either from the File menu or from the My Work tab. Record today's date. Then drag the table below into your journal and fill it out.

content.name: After each activity, please record what you know, wonder, and learn about the topic.

text: Objective
How can we identify and measure the activity of muscles? During this lesson, you will use Electromyography (EMG) to investigate your own muscle activity.
Visualize and Record Muscle Activity

Let’s measure your muscle activity! In order to make muscle activity usable as data to drive Bionics, we need to be able to measure it. For this, we will use EMG sensors, which measure the electrical activity that occurs when you contract or expand your muscles.
For this activity you will need the following materials:
Muscle SpikerShield (yellow board) coupled with an Arduino board (blue). The Muscle SpikerShield allows you to record your muscle's electrical activity (known as Electromyography or EMG).
Orange Muscle Electrode Cable with 3 alligator clips (two reds, one black).
Smartphone Data Cable and an Adapter. This cable connects the Muscle SpikerShield to a smartphone to visualize the muscle data. You will also need an adapter to connect the cable to your smartphone.
Sticker electrodes - used to pick up electrical signals from your muscles.
A smartphone with the Backyard Brains Spike Recorder App. You can download the app for free from the App store or Google Play.
One (1) 9 V Battery and a hand grip (optional).
Procedure
1. Connect the 9V battery to the Arduino board (blue board)

2. Connect the smartphone data cable (the green cable) to the Muscle SpikerShield green connector. Make sure you connect the end of the green cable labeled as “SpikerBox” to the Muscle SpikerShield. The other end (labeled as “Smartphone”) should be connected to your smartphone (via the provided adapter).

3. Decide who is going to be the study participant (you can take turns). Place two electrode stickers on the participant’s forearm close to each other and another one on the participant’s elbow (this is the reference electrode)
4. Connect the orange muscle electrode cable (the one with the three alligators) to the Muscle SpikerShield orange connector:
5. Connect the two red alligators to the electrodes on your arm. The black cable should be connected to the reference electrode:
6. Open the Backyard Brains Spike Recorder App on your phone. Your screen should look similar to this:
Pinch to change the time scale (horizontal axis) to 1.5 - 2 seconds. You can also change the y-axis scale if needed.
Hold the hand grip and squeeze it (or just make a fist if you don’t have a hand grip). How does the display changes when you use your arm muscles?
Now, it is time to reflect on the activity as a group! Use this space to discuss:

• How does muscle activity vary between one’s dominant vs. non-dominant hand?
  • How does muscle activity vary between different muscles (e.g., forearm vs. forehead muscles)?
  • How does muscle activity vary between agonist and antagonist muscles?
  • What happens when we activate our hand muscles for an extended period of time using a hand gripper?
  • Can you predict who’s going to win an arm-wrestling contest based on the contestants’ muscle activity?
Please document your observations in your team's EMG journal.

columns.name: Question
values: How does muscle activity vary between one’s dominant vs. non-dominant hand?
How does muscle activity vary between different muscles (e.g., forearm vs. forehead muscles)?
How does muscle activity vary between agonist and antagonist muscles? (see here)
What happens when one activates their arm muscles for an extended period of time using a hand gripper (see here)?
Can you predict who would win an arm wrestling contest based on the contestants’ muscle activity?

columns.name: Claim (a statement in response to question, supported by evidence)
values: Compared to the dominant hand, the non-dominant hand’s muscle activity….

columns.name: Evidence (may insert screen shots or images of illustrations)

text: DISCUSS
Now, it is time to reflect on the activity as class!

• Why does gathering EMG signals matter to you, your family, or others in the community?
  • Why does this matter to scientists, physicians, physical therapists, athletic trainers, and/or biomedical engineers?
  • How may gathering EMG data inform the design of a device that can help people with neurological conditions or missing limbs?

Here is a program that will display several different types of simulated EMG data that can show you some of the issues with using that data to manipulate another device. Drag this program into your Workspace, and choose from one of the three types of EMG demo data. Consider and describe the issues associated with using this data.
KWL JOURNAL

You will keep a journal of what you have learned throughout these lessons. Begin or Open a KWL Journal either from the File menu or from the My Work tab. Record today's date. Then drag the table below into your journal and fill it out.

content.name: After each activity, please record what you know, wonder, and learn about the topic.

problems.title: Lesson 1.5 - How to control a robotic gripper

text: How can EMG signals be used to control a robotic gripper?
Objective

During this section, we will explore how EMG signals can be used to control a robotic gripper. For that, you will use electromyography (EMG) in coordination with a robotic gripper to model the performance of a bionic arm.

tiles.title: Sketch of muscle control of a robot gripper

text: Let’s learn how to control a robotic gripper with muscle sensors! In this activity, you can choose 'Simulation' or the Arduino analog input pins with the materials illustrated below to visualize your real-time muscle movements and control a gripper with your muscle sensors. You can also either select a gripper simulation or work with the analog gripper to observe the real-time changes.
Setting up the Analog Muscle Sensors & Gripper:
Materials:
You will need all the materials from the previous activity (image below) with the following additions (image on the right): (1) A robotic gripper; (2) An Arduino USB cable (blue cable)

tiles.title: Arduino kit components to get EMG signals into Dataflow

text: Setting up:
1. Connect the blue cable to the Arduino board and then connect the other end of the blue cable to your computer’s USB port:

2. Connect the gripper to the Muscle SpikerShield (the yellow board). Note that there is a cable coming out of the gripper with three wires (yellow, red, and black). Look closely at the Muscle SpikerShield (the yellow board on top of the Arduino). Next to the gray-ish box, there are three pins labeled “Y” (for yellow), “R” (red), and “B” (black). Gently connect the gripper to the Muscle SpikerShield as shown here:
3. Power up the gripper, connect a 9V battery to the Muscle SpikerShield (the yellow board):

4. Decide who is going to be the study participant (you can take turns). Place two electrode stickers on the participant’s forearm close to each other and another one on the participant’s elbow (this is the reference electrode)
5. Connect the orange muscle electrode cable (the one with the three alligators) to the Muscle SpikerShield orange connector:
6. Connect the two red alligators to the electrodes on your arm. The black cable should be connected to the reference electrode:
Programming

You can read the input signals from the muscle sensors using a sensor block in a Dataflow program tile. You can drive either the simulated or the real output claw using these sensors, or you can 'condition' the muscle signal first. There are lots of ways the following very simple program can be improved.

When you first try to read an EMG signal or send signals to the grabber, you must click the gray lightning bolt button in the top left corner of the Dataflow tile to connect it to the Arduino. This is known as 'pairing' and it's the same as the instructions you might use to send music from your phone to a speaker.
Explanation of the above code blocks (not for students):

In this activity, there is only one muscle (EMG) sensor. Students can choose one of the 'Demo’ inputs or a connected Arduino. When the student choses 'BB EMG’ from the Sensor block menu then they will get a browser dialog allowing them to select the hardware for real-time data input.
The app visualizes the muscle electrical activity, allowing students to change the vertical scale of the signal with the ‘+’ and ‘-’ buttons.

Once a logic block is added, a horizontal threshold line is superimposed on the EMG data. Students can then choose an operation (e.g., ‘Greater than’) and enter a value (e.g., ‘8’). The horizontal red line (i.e., the threshold) shifts up/down accordingly.
Next, students add an ‘action’ and an ‘output device’ blocks.
Output: Students can either choose ‘Simulation’ for a simulated output device (a basic gripper that opens and closes) or one of the Arduino’s digital outputs to control an external device.
Under ‘Action’, students choose a specific movement (e.g., ‘close’). Some types of movements have additional parameters, like speed (in this case, how fast the gripper closes).
When the signal rises above the threshold the gripper closes, and when the signal drops below the threshold the gripper opens.
The logic block might need to detect if the EMG crosses the threshold with a rising or falling edge. The polarity of the cross may inform whether the gripper opens or closes.
TIP: While interacting with the gripper, pay close attention to how you could make it work better. Some options to consider are:

• Changing the locations of the electrodes. For example, students may have more success controlling the gripper by placing the EMG electrodes on the fleshy part below their pinky and the reference electrode by their thumb.
  • Changing the sensitivity of the device by pressing the gray button the Muscle SpikerShield.
  • Adding or editing the parameters and nodes in the Dataflow control program
  • Grasping objects of different sizes/weights.
Now, it is time to reflect on the activity as a group! Add tiles in your workspace to:

• Evaluate the strengths and weaknesses of the EMG-controlled gripper and summarize your ideas in a table format.
  • Reflect on how the design of the gripper can be improved and please sketch out your ideas.
  • The Demo Output node in the Dataflow program blocks has a more advanced gripper. Try some programs with that and reflect on how this is an improvement on the existing device.
  • Reflect back on the video with the young woman at the opening of the unit, discuss how a device like the gripper can serve her in her day-to-day life.
Open your Journal and add a copy of the table below to document this activity.

content.name: After each activity, please record what you know, wonder, and learn about the topic.

problems.title: Lesson 2.1 - How does touch impact movement?

text: Lesson 2.1 Overview
Today let's talk about how sensory input impacts our ability to move and interact with objects.

Materials: For every two students:

  • A 30 cm ruler
  • Winter gloves
Lesson Resources
Watch this video PBS News Hour story about how technology could be used to improve the function of prosthetic limbs.

Think about the EMG-controlled grabber we built in the previous lesson and discuss some challenges you might encounter when trying to hold an egg with the grabber. How would you improve the design of the system to overcome these challenges? Document some ideas in your workspace. You can use images, drawings, text or programs to record your ideas.
REACTION TIME AND TOUCH

In Lesson 1.2 you measured reaction time using a ruler, comparing your dominant and non-dominant hands. Today we will conduct a similar experiment to investigate how tactile information impacts reaction time (in other words, if we can feel the ruler with our fingertips, how does this impacts how fast we are at catching it?.

Discuss with your group how to modify the reaction time experiment to answer this new research question. Design a new data recording table, similar to the one in Lesson 1.2, that allows you to record reaction time with and without a winter glove.
Conduct your experiment as designed and record your findings here. Assign one member of the group to collect all the data from the groupmates and publish it to the class.

With your group, discuss how prosthetic arms can be improved by incorporating sensory information (similar to the prosthetic leg example from the video). Sketch your ideas and consider how the motor command from the brain interacts with tactile information from objects.
KWL JOURNALS
Using your KWL journal, add new rows to the table to add to what you know, wonder, and learned about the role of tactile information in movement.

problems.title: Lesson 2.2 - How do we perceive touch?

text: In the last lesson we discussed how sensory information impacts movement?. Today we will explore how the nervous system processes sensory (and more specifically tactile) information. We'll speculate together on what problems could arise in this process.

In today’s activity, you and your group will measure touch sensitivity across different parts of your body to create a model of your sense of touch. You will use a web site called Brainmapper.org to make this model called a “homunculus”. The model will help us understand how the brain processes touch.
Lesson Resources
Read the information on the Brainmapper website about the science of brain receptor density to each part of your body.
https://brainmapper.org/
Follow the instructions below, and enter measurements into https://brainmapper.org/(Experiment tab → Enter the Results).
Homunculus mapping
Decide who is going to be the experimenter and who will be the test subject (you should take turns such that all team members will be a test subject once).

1. The test subject should close their eyes.
  2. The experimenter should gently press the caliper’s jaws against the skin of the test subject, and ask them if they feel one point or two points of contact (the two points need to touch the skin at the same time).
  3. Set the caliper’s jaw at a distance of 60mm (6cm) and keep testing smaller and smaller distances (30mm, 15mm, 7.5mm, 3.75mm) until the subject indicates that they feel one point only.
  4. Test the forehead, back, arm, palm of the hand, leg, and feet as shown in the pictures in any order.
  5. Record the first distance that the subject felt as one point (or the last distance that was tested) in the table - drag the table into your Workspace so you can fill it out for each person you test.
  6. Enter these numbers at https://brainmapper.org/experiment/ and take a screenshot of the resulting homunculus. You can then upload your homunculus into your Workspace by creating an image tile and dragging or uploading the image from your desktop into the tile.
Enter the shortest distance the subject felt two distinct points.

Discuss the following questions with your group and record your answers in your workspace. Assign one group menber to collect the answers and publish them to the class:

  1. What is the most/least sensitive body part?
  2. Why do different parts of the body have different sensitivity to touch?
  3. Were there differences between students in their touch sensitivity? What can explain these differences?

Read this blurb on the neuroscience of touch. Identify which body parts are involved in processing touch information and make an annotated model that shows how they are connected to each other. Assign members of your group to research the following parts of the body and how they process touch:

  • Touch receptors
  • Sensory nerves
  • Spinal cord
  • Thalamus
  • Somatosensory cortex.

Brainfacts.org is a good source of information and has a 3D model of the brain.

Extension activity: Compare your model to the one created in Lesson 1.3 (control of movement).
Using your KWL journal in the My Work > KWL Journal tab, add a new row to your table that describes what you know, wonder, and learned about the role of tactile information in movement.
Can you grab an egg (with the gripper) without cracking it?
Materials:

• A gripper kit
  • Two gripper “mittens”, one will be a regular plastic attachment, the other will have a pressure sensor on it (see picture →)
  • 10 kΩ ohm resistor
  • 1 breadboard
  • 2 segments of wire
  • A plastic egg or a drained egg
Assembly:
1. Set up your gripper like normal. If you are stuck, reference the gripper directions in Lesson 1.5. Attach the “pressure sensor mittens” to each side of the gripper, like in the picture.
2. Grab the materials listed above and lay them out.
3. Find the tiny breadboard.
4. Place the 10K Ω (Brown - Black - Orange color bands on the resistor) resistor across the center of the board:

5. Take one of the wires coming out of the pressure sensor and plug it to the 5V socket in the Arduino. (4th space.) Note: The wires coming from the pressure sensor may need the wire ends to be twisted a bit to fit well into the breadboard and Arduino.
6. Take the other wire that is coming out of the pressure sensor and plug it to the left side of the 10K Ω resistor in the same row as the resistor:

7. Take a segment of wire. Plug one end to the ground socket (either the second or third space) of the Arduino and the other one to the opposite side as the pressure wire of the of the 10K Ω resistor. This completes the circuit, allowing current to flow through the pressure sensor and the 10 kΩ resistor.
8. Take another segment of wire. Plug one end to socket A1 in the Arduino. The other end should be connected to the same side as the pressure wire of the 10 K Ω resistor.

9. CONGRATULATIONS! You’ve just built a force sensing circuit. This circuit works like this: as force is applied to the pressure sensor on the gripper mitten, more electrical current flows through the circuit. As more current flows through the 10 kΏ resistor, the voltage across the resistor increases. We will measure the voltage changes using the Arduino (this is why the red wire from the circuit is connected to A1.)

10. Connect your Arduino shield to your computer using the same cabling from Lesson 1.5. Create a Dataflow programming tile in your Workspace. You can also copy the one shown here by dragging it into your Workspace. Open up two sensor blocks and select EMG in one and Surface Pressure in the other. You will need to choose "connect for live ..." from one sensor block, and use the lightning bolt connection button in the left corner of the Dataflow screen to connect the program to the sensor input. Once you do, you should begin to see readings show up in the block output fields. Is there a response on the screen? If not, check your circuit.

Next, try to use the gripper to pick up an object by dragging this program into your Workspace and pairing the arduino devices with it. This program does two main things: (1) when a muscle is contracted, the signal is detected and triggers the claw to close. (2) When something presses against the force sensor, the voltage increase across the 10 kΏ resistor is detected and tells the claw to stop gripping. This is meant to prevent the claw from closing too strongly on the target (egg) and damaging it.
13. When the program is in your workspace and you've paired with your Arduino setup, make sure that you can cause the gripper to close by clenching your muscles.
14. To test the force sensor, try pinching the sensor and contracting your muscle. Does the gripper move? Why or why not?
What is the purpose of the Control block? Why are there so many conditions to check in the three logic blocks?

tiles.title: Pressure feedback to keep claw from closing too far

text: Evaluate your group's design and discuss what can be improved. Think about the young woman who was portrayed in the video at the opening of the unit. How would touch sensors serve her in her day-to-day life? How the device could be further improved or modified? What other kinds of sensors might be employed to mimic human function?
Write in your KWL Journal and reflect on this lesson.

Prosthetics can help people live full productive lives. Robotically enhanced prosthetics can mimic organic limbs even more closely and sometimes can make prosthetics functional for people who could not benefit from non-interactive technology.

In this lesson you will have the opportunity to design robotic solutions for one of several end users. Each case has different features to it. You should consider the specific issues to solve and brainstorm solutions with your group.

Review the engineering design process document linked below. You will embark on the first step – empathize – by researching the experiences and challenges of someone who has a sensory or motor condition in the following lab section. Your group should select from among the case studies in the Lab.
Resource:
Design Thinking protocol
Design Journal Template
Who is your team helping?
What are the challenges experienced by this person?
Why is it important to help reduce these challenges?
How can we apply what we have learned throughout the unit to help this person?
Mrs. Marcus

Maria Marcus is 84 years old. When she was younger she worked as a pharmacist. This required routine use of her hands as she measured and mixed medicines that were able to restore the health of community members. Mrs. Marcus is enjoying her retirement, with ample time to bake for her nine grandchildren and maintain her flower garden with her husband of 60 years.

Recently Mrs. Marcus is unsettled to find that arthritis in her hands has resulted in something her primary care physician, Dr. Romero, has diagnosed as hypoesthesia. Hypoesthesia is reduced or complete loss of sensation. In Mrs. Marcus’s case, Dr. Romero believes that inflammation of joints in Mrs. Marcus’s hands are pressing against the surrounding nerves, resulting in numbness. This is unsafe, especially given Mrs. Marcus is unable to sense temperature and touch in her fingers when she bakes.
Tilly

Tilly Lockey lost her hands at fifteen months of age due to a bacterial infection. After eleven years without hands, Tilley received a pair of bionic hands. Now sixteen years old, she is now able to open doors and cupboards without the help of her parents or sister. Tilly feels empowered by this new-found independence. She also likes to design the plastic outer cases of her bionic arms, which has become an important part of expressing who she is.

As you noticed in the video, Tilly is happy to be able to more easily apply makeup with her bionic hands. However, Tilly finds it difficult to do some of the eye makeup techniques she found on Instagram. Tilly would like to be able to apply false lashes on her own, but her current bionic hands are unable to pick up and hold delicate objects.

tiles.title: Tilly applies makeup with bionic hands

text: Mr. Johnson

Isaiah Johnson is 72 years old. When he was younger he worked as a social worker at the local Veterans Administration Medical Center. Mr. Johnson found it very rewarding to help people navigate challenges. Now that he is retired, Mr. Johnson has been spending more time volunteering with his wife Janelle at the community food garden they had initiated just before the birth of their second child.

Shortly after he was drafted to serve in the Vietnam War, at nineteen years of age, Mr. Johnson lost his sense of sight during an explosion in which shrapnel struck his face. Mr. Johnson’s guide dog, a golden labrador named Rex, helps Mr. Johnson safely stroll across the city’s sidewalks and streets. Recently Mrs. Johnson had hip surgery, and Mr. Johnson came to realize he is not as independent as he thought. As Mrs. Johnson recuperated on a rented electric hospital bed in the living room, Mr. Johnson prepared stove top and microwave meals. As he began to prepare Mrs. Johnson’s favorite pot roast, he realized that it would be unsafe to use the oven because he would not sense where the hot cast iron skillet was located. This frustrated Mr. Johnson, who has taken pride in his ability to live life fully despite eye damage.

tiles.title: Mr. Johnson and his seeing eye dog

text: After you have completed illustrated and annotated models of your proposed products, publish your workspace to the class to share the design, including the design considerations that ensure Mrs.Marcus/Tilly would find the product

• easy to use,
  • safe,
  • useful, and
  • comfortable.
Open your KWL Journal and add a row to the table to document your thoughts.
